Assignment 1: Inline & Block Elements

Do some research on inline and block level HTML elements. Using a little CSS for simple styles, (color, type, etc) make a visual representation of those elements and their natural behavior.

display: block;

display: block

What does it do? The element is displayed as a block-level element which takes up the full width available. Block-level elements force new lines.

h1
p

Fig A: Default block-display for headers and paragraphs.

Other elements with default block-display include:

  • div: all-purpose box
  • h1-h6: headings
  • p: paragraphs
  • ul, ol, li lists and list items

display: inline

display: inline


What does it do? The element is displayed as an inline-level element (like a span). The element will only take up as much width as needed. Inline elements do not force new lines.

p - example one
p - example two


Fig A: Two paragraphs with an inline style.

li
li
li

Fig B: Default list style using display block.

li
li
li


Fig C: The same list with display inline added. Now we have a horizontal list perfect for navigations. Note: Inline elements ignore widths and heights.

li
li
li

Fig D: List with display inline-block added. Now we can define widths, heights, margins and padding. More on inline-block below.

This red text uses a span with an inline style. Other elements with a default inline style:

  • span: all-purpose inline element
  • a: anchor for links
  • strong: makes text bold
  • em: makes text italic

display: inline-block;

display: inline-block

What does it do? The element is placed as an inline element (on the same line as adjacent content), but it behaves as a block element. This allows you to set a width and height, top and bottom margins and paddings.

p
p

Fig A: Two paragraphs with inline-block style added. Paragraphs are now placed next to one another on the same line.

h1
p
p

Fig B: A block-level element with two inline-block elements.

h1 { display: block; }
p { display: inline-block; }
p { display: inline-block; }
